docTitle.titlePart:
All-optical ultra-fast 2x2 switch based on XPM-induced
polarization rotation in highly nonlinear fiber

byline.docAuthor: Paolo Ghelfi, Antonella Bogoni, and Luca Potì

front.div:
Abstract: An all-optical ultra-fast 2x2 spatial switch based on polarization rotation induced by Cross-Phase-
Modulation in highly non-linear fiber is presented. Bit-Error-Rate measurements confirm the effectiveness of
the proposed scheme and its suitability in cascaded configurations.
front.keyword: OCIS codes: (190.3270) Kerr effect; (200.4740) Optical processing
front.div:
1. Introduction
The virtually unlimited bandwidth of optical fibers has caused a great increase in data transmission speed over the
past decade, hence stimulating high-demand multimedia services. Nowadays, opto-electronic conversion is still
required at each network node to process the incoming signals. However, when the bit rate of the single channel
increases beyond electronic speed limit, all-optical processing must be performed to extract the routing information
from the incoming packets and switch them to the selected node output. Besides, all-optical packet switching can
offer transparency to data rate and format, fine granularity and flexibility, reducing the packet latency time as well.
Up to now, few optical technologies are capable of ultra-short switching time (<100ps). SOAs and non-linear
fiber-based switches are most promising candidates [1,2], but only the latter are fast enough to operate at ultra-high
speed. Few 2x2 fiber-based switches have been proposed so far [3], usually in interferometric schemes which
improve the switching efficiency. Recently the new generation of Highly Non-Linear Fibers (HNLF) is allowing
efficient nonlinear effects reducing the fiber length, avoiding the use of interferometers and increasing the device
compactness and stability at the same time.
In this paper we report a simple scheme of a 2x2 all-optical ultra-fast switch based on signal polarization
rotation [4] induced in HNLF by Cross Phase Modulation (XPM). The switch provides a space domain deflection
routing policy, preserving the wavelength of the incoming signal, and it can be used as basic block for the design of
further NxN switches. The effectiveness of the proposed scheme and its suitability in cascaded configurations are
confirmed by Bit Error Rate (BER) measurements carried out in both bar and cross configuration.
